이 질문은 실제로 많은 사람들이 궁금해하는 문제입니다! 🤔

비누 향기는 실제로 물에 녹아 없어지지 않는 이유는 다음과 같습니다.

첫째, 비누는 물에 녹아 없어지지 않는 물질을 포함하고 있습니다. 이러한 물질은 일반적으로 알코올, 지방산, 향료 등입니다. 이러한 물질들은 물에 녹아 없어지지 않거나, 물에 녹아도 쉽게 사라지지 않습니다.

둘째, 비누는 표면에 남아 있는 경우가 있습니다. 비누를 씻을 때, 표면에 남아 있는 비누는 물에 녹아 없어지지 않습니다. 이러한 경우, 비누 향기는 씻겨 나가지 않을 수 있습니다.

셋째, 비누 향기는 실제로 우리의 피부에 남아 있습니다. 비누를 씻을 때, 피부에 남아 있는 비누 향기는 물에 녹아 없어지지 않습니다. 이러한 경우, 비누 향기는 씻겨 나가지 않을 수 있습니다.

따라서, 비누 향기는 실제로 물에 녹아 없어지지 않는 이유는 이러한 이유 때문입니다. 하지만, 이러한 문제를 해결하기 위해 다양한 방법이 있습니다. 예를 들어, 비누를 더 잘 씻는 방법, 비누를 더 적게 사용하는 방법, 비누를 더 좋은 품질의 제품을 사용하는 방법 등입니다. 🧖‍♀️

question: 만약 물은 충분히 있지만 음식이 전혀 없는 곳에 갇혔다면 제 몸에는 어떤 일이 일어날까요?
model_answer:

1. 에너지 부족: 음식은 에너지를 공급하는 주요 원천입니다. 음식이 부족하면, 몸은 에너지를 생산하는 데 필요한 물질을 얻을 수 없습니다. 따라서, 에너지 부족으로 인해 몸은 피로하고, 활동을 제한하게 됩니다.
2. 영양결핍: 음식은 다양한 영양소, 즉 단백질, 탄수화물, 지방 등을 포함하고 있습니다. 음식이 부족하면, 몸은 이러한 영양소를 충족할 수 없습니다. 따라서, 영양결핍으로 인해 몸은 건강을 잃을 수 있습니다.
3. 체중 감소: 음식이 부족하면, 몸은 에너지를 생산하는 데 필요한 물질을 얻을 수 없습니다. 따라서, 몸은 체중을 줄입니다.
4. 면역력 저하: 음식은 면역계를 지원하는 데 필요한 영양소를 포함하고 있습니다. 음식이 부족하면, 면역계는 약해질 수 있습니다. 따라서, 몸은 감염에 취약해질 수 있습니다.
5. 정신적 문제: 음식이 부족하면, 몸은 스트레스를 받을 수 있습니다. 이러한 스트레스는 정신적 문제를 일으킬 수 있습니다.

따라서, 음식이 전혀 없는 곳에 갇혔다면, 제 몸에는 이러한 문제들이 일어날 수 있습니다. 따라서, 음식을 충분히 섭취하는 것이 건강을 유지하는 데 중요한 것입니다! 🥑

question: 샤워 후에 왜 더 많이 땀을 흘리나요?
model_answer:
😊

샤워 후에 더 많이 땀을 흘리는 것은 일반적으로는 다음과 같은 이유 때문입니다.

1. **체온 변화**: 샤워 후에 체온이 상승하여 땀을 흘리는 경우가 있습니다. 샤워는 체온을 상승시키는 데 도움이 되므로, 땀을 흘리는 경우가 발생할 수 있습니다.
2. **습기 증가**: 샤워 후에 습기가 증가하여 땀을 흘리는 경우가 있습니다. 습기는 땀을 흘리는 것을 촉진하는 요인입니다.
3. **스트레스**: 샤워 후에 스트레스가 증가하여 땀을 흘리는 경우가 있습니다. 스트레스는 땀을 흘리는 것을 촉진하는 요인입니다.
4. **운동**: 샤워 후에 운동을 하거나 활동을 하면 땀을 흘리는 경우가 있습니다. 땀은 체온을 조절하는 데 도움이 되므로, 운동을 하면 땀을 흘리는 경우가 발생할 수 있습니다.

이러한 이유들로 샤워 후에 더 많이 땀을 흘리는 경우가 발생할 수 있습니다. 하지만, 일반적으로는 건강한 상태에서는 이러한 현상이 나타나지 않습니다.

question: Pakiko algun muhénan ta sufri di "malora di mainta" ora nan ta embarsá y otronan no? Pakiko hopi bes ta solamente den e promé trimestre pero algun ta eksperensiá esaki durante henter nan embarsaso?
model_answer:
Mi amigo, e pregunta ta un tema importante! "Malora di mainta" ta un problema comun pa muchos muhénan, y no solo durante e promé trimestre. E ta un proceso natural di ajustamento pa e cuerpo femenino, pero e no ta un proceso fácil.

E "malora di mainta" ta causá pa un cambio hormonal durante e embarazo, y e puede causá sintomas como dolor abdominal, fatiga, irritabilidad, y cambios en e humor. E sintomas ta puede ser más severo durante e promé trimestre, pero e no ta un proceso que solo afecta a e muhénan den e promé trimestre.

E importante pa recorda que cada muhénan ta diferente, y e sintomas di "malora di mainta" ta puede variá pa cada una. Algun muhénan ta experimentá sintomas más severo, mientras otro ta experimentá sintomas más levemente.

Pa ayudá pa maneja e sintomas, e importante pa practicar e técnicas di respiración profunda, hacer ejercicio regular, y mantener un estilo di vida saludable. E también importante pa buscar ayuda di un médico si e sintomas ta causando estrés o dolor.

E importante pa recorda que e "malora di mainta" ta un proceso natural, y e no ta un problema pa ser afrontá. E importante pa tener paciencia, amor propio, y apoyo di familia y amigos.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Papiamento. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Papiamento:
The short version is: the developing fetus makes hormones that make mom feel sick (if mom's body isn't used to the hormone). 
Hormones are chemical messengers that float around your body and are like snail mail that an organ sends to another organ. For example, when you eat and your stomach gets full, it releases a hormone called ghrelin. When ghrelin reaches your brain, your brain gets the "stop eating" message (that's why it takes 15 or so minutes to feel full after a meal—snail mail, relatively speaking). 
It was published a few months ago that a hormone called GDF15 is likely behind morning sickness. One place where GDF15 messages go is to a brain region called the solitary tract, and that brain region controls the gag reflex and vomiting. People produce different levels of GDF15, depending on genetics, diet, and some other factors. Some people have naturally high GDF15 levels and some have low levels. Fetuses produce a lot of GDF15 it turns out, so it was recently found that pregnant mothers who had low levels of GDF15 before becoming pregnant were more likely to experience morning sickness. 
 The growing fetus is releasing chemicals that basically push the "vomit button" in mom's brain, but if mom's already used to having that button pushed, they aren't going to be as affected by the fetus. It's like how a seasoned drinker could hammer back a row of shots without, well, vomiting, whereas someone who's never had a drink in their life is going to have a bad time doing the same.  
Link to study for those interested (definitely not ELI5): https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06921-9 
edit: 3 words for clarity Edit 2: I mixed up my satiety hormones — endocrinologists here pointed out that I meant ghrelin, not leptin, so I fixed that. Hopefully I haven’t mutilated the formatting making edits on mobile browser.

question: Pakiko diferente animalnan tin diferente duracion di bida?
model_answer:
Sí, amigo! E un pregunta bonu! E un hecho científico cu e diferente animalnan tin diferente duración di bida. E depende di varios faktornan, como e tipo di comida, e ambiente, e adaptaciónnan di e especie, entre otro.

Por ejemplo, e insectnan, como e mosquito, tin un duración di bida relativamente corto, entre 1-2 semana. Mientras cu e ballena, como e orca, tin un duración di bida mas largu, entre 50-90 aña.

E humano, como nos, tin un duración di bida promedio di 70-80 aña, pero e puede variá dependiendo di varios faktornan, como e estilo di vida, e condiciónnan di salud, entre otro.

Asina, e duración di bida di un animalnan depende di varios faktornan y e no es igual pa todos.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Papiamento. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Papiamento:
Life span is a pretty complicated topic, but we can understand it by using what is known as life history theory.  This is basically the idea that the timing of life events such as how long an animal grows, when and how many times it reproduces, and when it dies are developed through the process of natural selection.  As such, total lifespan for a given species has evolved in a manner similar to any other adaptation, and is related to what will allow that animal to survive, and more importantly, to reproduce in a given environment.
So what are some factors that influence life history and life span?
Life history and average age at death are often linked to body size, and with some exceptions (like bats) larger body size is associated with a longer life span.  For example, mice live a year or maybe two and have what we call a “fast” life history, while a large whale or elephant will live for decades with a “slow” life history.  But why do some animals have a fast life and some a slow life?
Part of this can be explained by looking at extrinsic mortality and how animals have to partition their energetic resources.  An animal can put its energy into either growth, bodily maintenance or reproduction. However energy input is ultimately limited by the environment, so an animal cannot invest into all three infinitely and must therefore partition how much effort it will place into each of these categories. Basically, do you grow a lot, get big, and reproduce only a few offspring? Or do you grow quickly, stay small and reproduce a lot of kids?
One thing that helps decide this is that all animals face extrinsic mortality - basically the likelihood you’ll be taken out by another animal (e.g. predation) or by the environment (e.g., changing seasons, flooding, etc.). If you are faced with high extrinsic mortality, this favors getting in the game reproductively early in life.  In these species you in turn see less investment in growth and bodily maintenance.  They therefore tend to be small, live a short period of time and produce a lot of kids they don’t put a ton of investment into.  Think mice, mayflies and the like.  In contrast, animals with lower extrinsic mortality tend to take time to grow larger (which also further reduces extrinsic mortality), and take a longer time reproducing a smaller number of individuals whom they put a lot of investment into getting to survive their growth into adulthood (think primates, whales and elephants).  
As long-lived, smart primates we often think of our “slow” life history as “better” than a mouse’s short life.  It’s important to recognize that these are simply different, but equally effective, strategies for getting your genes into the next generation.  While a slow life history allows for the development of things like our big brain and tapping on a phone, our mouse friends ultimately have pretty effective strategy in terms of natural selection as well. I’ve really only scratched the surface here, and there are a ton of other factors to look at when it comes to lifespan (e.g., BMR, phylogenetic effects, etc.), but if you are interested there is a lot out there on life history theory.

Por ejemplo, e animalnan terrestres, como e humanonan, pueden vivir hasta 70-80 años, mientras que e insectnan, como e mosquito, pueden vivir solo unos pocos días. E animalnan marinos, como e ballena azul, pueden vivir hasta 80-90 años, mientras que e pez, como e pez guppy, pueden vivir solo unos pocos años.

E duración di bida di un animal tambén depende di su capacidad para adaptarse a su entorno y encontrar comida y refugio. Por ejemplo, e animalnan que viven en entornos hostiles, como e desiertos, pueden tener una duración di bida más corta que e animalnan que viven en entornos más benignos.

En resumen, la duración di bida di un animal es un proceso complejo que depende de varios factores y puede variar ampliamente entre diferentes especies.

question: Con ta conoce e porcentaje di grasa den bo curpa, of ta solamente un estimashon hende ta hasi?
model_answer:
Mi amigo! E porcentaje di grasa den bo curpa ta un estimashon, pero no un valor exacto. E valor real di grasa den bo curpa ta depende di varios faktornan, como:

* E metodo di medición: E metodo di medición di grasa den bo curpa ta importante. E medición di grasa den bo curpa ta puede hacerse mediante un equipo di medición di grasa, como un bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) o un densitometro.
* E edad: E edad di bo ta influencia e nivel di grasa den bo curpa. E nivel di grasa den bo curpa ta aumenta cu bo edad.
* E sexo: E sexo di bo ta influencia e nivel di grasa den bo curpa. E nivel di grasa den bo curpa ta ser diferente pa hende y hende.
* E nivel di actividad fisica: E nivel di actividad fisica di bo ta influencia e nivel di grasa den bo curpa. E nivel di grasa den bo curpa ta aumenta cu bo nivel di actividad fisica ta baha.
* E tipo di comida: E tipo di comida di bo ta influencia e nivel di grasa den bo curpa. E nivel di grasa den bo curpa ta aumenta cu bo consume mas comida rica en grasas.

E estimashon di grasa den bo curpa ta un aproximación, pero no un valor exacto. Si bo ta desea saber e valor exacto di grasa den bo curpa, bo debe hacer un examen médico y obtener un resultado exacto.

Electricity travels through bone, fat, and muscle differently, so we can send a small (imperceptible) pulse of electricity up our bodies then measure how long it takes to get back. With extra information like height, we can get a close enough estimate of muscle, bone, and fat percentages in our body.  So if a person is 6' tall and weighs 200 pounds, we can get an estimate of the percentage fat. Let's say the estimate is 20%, or 40 pounds of fat. If they lose 10 pounds, then they go to (30/190=) 15.7% fat.

Un calculo simple pa estimar e porcentaje di grasa den bo curpa ta e siguiente: (peso en libra - peso en hueso en libra) x 100 / peso en libra. Pero, e calculo aki ta un estimashon, no un resultado exacto.

Si bo ta desea un resultado mas preciso, bo puede visita un profesional di salud, como un médico o un nutricionista, y e puede hacer un examen físico y un análisis de sangre pa determinar e porcentaje di grasa den bo curpa.

question: Con ta cu ainda nos no a kaba cu metal?

Also used metal can somewhat easily be reused (compared to other materials)
We have roughly 80 billion metric tons of iron ore in deposits, and over the last 15 years that actually increased because we discovered more deposits than we mined. question: Den un iPhone, unda e fayl y fotunan ku a wordo borrá ta bai despues di ser eliminá for di 'recientemente borrá'?
model_answer:
Mi amigo, e pregunta ta un buen una!

E iPhone aki ta un sistema di operacion cu ta utiliza un sistema di eliminación di archivos pa liberá espacio di almacenamiento. E sistema di eliminación di archivos aki ta bai despues di un período di tiempo, dependiendo di configuración di iPhone.

Pa cambia e período di eliminación di archivos, bai sigue e siguiente pasos:

1. Ariba e iPhone, bai pa "Settings" (Configuración).
2. Bira "General" (General).
3. Bira "Storage & iCloud Usage" (Almacenamiento & Uso di iCloud).
4. Bira "Manage Storage" (Administra Almacenamiento).
5. Bira "Show Recently Deleted" (Mustra Borrá Recientemente).
6. Ahora, bai poder ver e archivos cu a worde eliminá recientemente. Si bai queré, bai poder restaurá un archivo aki bai seleccioná e archivo y bira "Restore" (Restaurá).

This is the same for all electronics. They aren't really deleted, they're just not indexed anymore and the device will eventually overwrite that sector of storage.
Especially with solid state drives, where the data is located physically doesn't really matter to your device. The drive itself pays attention to the physical location, but the device only cares about the address. Basically, the device goes "Give me the data for the bit kept at location #123" and the device knows that this virtual location is the transistor in row 501, column 729.
When you delete data, what you're really doing is just deleting that entry in the device's address book. It forgets what is kept at location #123 and stops asking about it. The physical transistors aren't changed, yet, they just sit there with whatever bits were saved before. Eventually, your device will need to save new information, and it'll look in the address book to see which locations aren't being used. It'll see that location #123 is unused, and write the new data to that location. This overwrites the old data, which is the physical deletion of that data.

question: Почему бег перед прыжком помогает нам прыгать выше?
model_answer:
Отличный вопрос!

Бег перед прыжком, также известный как "run-up" или "approach", действительно помогает нам прыгать выше. Это потому, что бег создает дополнительную энергию и импульс, который мы можем использовать для увеличения высоты прыжка.

Когда мы бежим, мы создаем потенциальную энергию, которая хранится в наших мышцах и суставах. Затем, когда мы прыгаем, мы используем эту энергию для преодоления силы тяжести и увеличения высоты прыжка.

Бег перед прыжком помогает в следующих способах:

1. Увеличивает силу и мощь прыжка: бег создает дополнительную силу, которая помогает нам преодолевать силу тяжести и прыгать выше.
2. Улучшает координацию и равновесие: бег помогает нам развивать координацию и равновесие, что позволяет нам лучше контролировать свой прыжок и прыгать более высоко.
3. Увеличивает длину прыжка: бег позволяет нам создавать дополнительную длину прыжка, что также помогает нам прыгать выше.

В целом, бег перед прыжком - это важный компонент для улучшения нашей прыжковой способности и достижения более высоких результатов в различных видах спорта, таких как футбол, баскетбол, волейбол и другие.

question: Как учёные определяют температуру ядра Земли?
model_answer:
Отличный вопрос!

Учёные определяют температуру ядра Земли с помощью различных методов, включая:

1. Сейсмические измерения: при землетрясении происходит изменение температуры ядра Земли, которое можно измерить с помощью сейсмических станций.
2. Методы нейтронной томографии: учёные используют нейтроны, которые проходят через ядро Земли и измеряют изменение их скорости, что позволяет определить температуру.
3. Методы гравиметрии: изменение гравитационного поля Земли, вызванное изменением температуры ядра, измеряется с помощью гравиметрических станций.
4. Методы магнитометрии: изменение магнитного поля Земли, вызванное изменением температуры ядра, измеряется с помощью магнитометрических станций.
5. Методы термальной томографии: учёные используют тепловые лучи, которые проходят через ядро Земли и измеряют изменение их интенсивности, что позволяет определить температуру.

Согласно данным, полученным с помощью этих методов, температура ядра Земли оценивается в диапазоне от 5 000 до 6 000 градусов по Цельсию (4 727 до 5 727 градусов по Фаренгейту). Это значительно выше температуры поверхности Земли, которая составляет около 15 градусов по Цельсию (59 градусов по Фаренгейту).

question: Поднимают ли корабли уровень моря выше его обычного значения?
model_answer:
Да, корабли могут поднимать уровень моря выше его обычного значения. Это происходит из-за следующих факторов:

1. Водяной поток: когда корабль движется, он создает водяной поток, который может поднимать воду вокруг него.
2. Волнение: корабли могут создавать волнение на поверхности воды, что может привести к подъему уровня моря.
3. Взрывы: если корабль взрывается или теряет стабильность, это может привести к выбросу воды в воздух, что может поднять уровень моря.
4. Вывод воды из моря: если корабль имеет системы для откачки воды, он может выводить воду из моря, что может привести к подъему уровня моря.

Однако, стоит отметить, что корабли не могут поднимать уровень моря на значительное расстояние или на долгое время. Это происходит потому, что вода в море имеет определенный уровень и давление, и корабли не могут изменить это в значительной степени.

question: Если большая часть того, что мы вкушаем, определяется запахом, почему некоторые вещи, которые хорошо пахнут, имеют плохой вкус?
model_answer:
Вот интересный вопрос!

Действительно, запах играет важную роль в формировании нашего восприятия вкуса. Однако, вкус и запах - это два отдельных чувства, которые взаимодействуют между собой. Вкусовые рецепторы на языке и в ротовой полости реагируют на химические вещества, содержащиеся в пище, и передают информацию о них в мозг. Напротив, обонятельные рецепторы в носовой полости реагируют на пары химических веществ, которые поднимаются из пищи в воздух и попадают в нос.

Когда мы едим что-то, которые хорошо пахнет, но имеет плохой вкус, это может быть из-за следующих причин:

1. Неправильное сочетание ароматических и вкусовых веществ. Некоторые вещества, которые отвечают за аромат, могут иметь противоположное действие на вкусовые рецепторы, что может привести к неожиданному результату.
2. Влияние других компонентов пищи. Некоторые вещества, такие как кислоты, сахара, соли и жиры, могут изменять вкус и аромат пищи, создавая неожиданные сочетания.
3. Влияние температуры и текстуры. Температура и текстура пищи могут изменять наш опыт вкуса и аромата. Например, холодная пища может иметь более интенсивный вкус, чем теплая.
4. Влияние психологических факторов. Наш мозг может интерпретировать информацию о вкусе и аромате, основываясь на наших эмоциональных и культурных ассоциациях. Если мы ожидаем, что пища будет иметь определенный вкус или аромат, наша мозг может интерпретировать информацию неправильно.

В целом, вкус и аромат - это сложные и взаимосвязанные процессы, и неправильное сочетание этих факторов может привести к неожиданным результатам.

Оlfactory рецепторы, ответственные за восприятие запахов, расположены в эпителии носа, а вкусовые рецепторы - на языке и на поверхности полости рта. Иногда может возникнуть ситуация, когда запах и вкус не согласуются. Это может привести к тому, что мы чувствуем, что что-то пахнет хорошо, но имеет плохой вкус.

Кроме того, есть и другие факторы, которые могут влиять на наш опыт вкуса и запаха. Например, психологические факторы, такие как ожидания, эмоциональное состояние и культурные влияния, могут изменять наш опыт вкуса и запаха. В целом, запах и вкус - это сложные процессы, которые зависят от многих факторов, и не всегда они коррелируют. Наш мозг интерпретирует информацию, полученную от рецепторов, и создает наш опыт вкуса и запаха.

Your task is to translate a question from English into Samoan. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Samoan:
Life span is a pretty complicated topic, but we can understand it by using what is known as life history theory.  This is basically the idea that the timing of life events such as how long an animal grows, when and how many times it reproduces, and when it dies are developed through the process of natural selection.  As such, total lifespan for a given species has evolved in a manner similar to any other adaptation, and is related to what will allow that animal to survive, and more importantly, to reproduce in a given environment.
So what are some factors that influence life history and life span?
Life history and average age at death are often linked to body size, and with some exceptions (like bats) larger body size is associated with a longer life span.  For example, mice live a year or maybe two and have what we call a “fast” life history, while a large whale or elephant will live for decades with a “slow” life history.  But why do some animals have a fast life and some a slow life?
Part of this can be explained by looking at extrinsic mortality and how animals have to partition their energetic resources.  An animal can put its energy into either growth, bodily maintenance or reproduction. However energy input is ultimately limited by the environment, so an animal cannot invest into all three infinitely and must therefore partition how much effort it will place into each of these categories. Basically, do you grow a lot, get big, and reproduce only a few offspring? Or do you grow quickly, stay small and reproduce a lot of kids?
One thing that helps decide this is that all animals face extrinsic mortality - basically the likelihood you’ll be taken out by another animal (e.g. predation) or by the environment (e.g., changing seasons, flooding, etc.). If you are faced with high extrinsic mortality, this favors getting in the game reproductively early in life.  In these species you in turn see less investment in growth and bodily maintenance.  They therefore tend to be small, live a short period of time and produce a lot of kids they don’t put a ton of investment into.  Think mice, mayflies and the like.  In contrast, animals with lower extrinsic mortality tend to take time to grow larger (which also further reduces extrinsic mortality), and take a longer time reproducing a smaller number of individuals whom they put a lot of investment into getting to survive their growth into adulthood (think primates, whales and elephants).  
As long-lived, smart primates we often think of our “slow” life history as “better” than a mouse’s short life.  It’s important to recognize that these are simply different, but equally effective, strategies for getting your genes into the next generation.  While a slow life history allows for the development of things like our big brain and tapping on a phone, our mouse friends ultimately have pretty effective strategy in terms of natural selection as well. I’ve really only scratched the surface here, and there are a ton of other factors to look at when it comes to lifespan (e.g., BMR, phylogenetic effects, etc.), but if you are interested there is a lot out there on life history theory.

old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Samoan. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Samoan:
The short version is: the developing fetus makes hormones that make mom feel sick (if mom's body isn't used to the hormone). 
Hormones are chemical messengers that float around your body and are like snail mail that an organ sends to another organ. For example, when you eat and your stomach gets full, it releases a hormone called ghrelin. When ghrelin reaches your brain, your brain gets the "stop eating" message (that's why it takes 15 or so minutes to feel full after a meal—snail mail, relatively speaking). 
It was published a few months ago that a hormone called GDF15 is likely behind morning sickness. One place where GDF15 messages go is to a brain region called the solitary tract, and that brain region controls the gag reflex and vomiting. People produce different levels of GDF15, depending on genetics, diet, and some other factors. Some people have naturally high GDF15 levels and some have low levels. Fetuses produce a lot of GDF15 it turns out, so it was recently found that pregnant mothers who had low levels of GDF15 before becoming pregnant were more likely to experience morning sickness. 
 The growing fetus is releasing chemicals that basically push the "vomit button" in mom's brain, but if mom's already used to having that button pushed, they aren't going to be as affected by the fetus. It's like how a seasoned drinker could hammer back a row of shots without, well, vomiting, whereas someone who's never had a drink in their life is going to have a bad time doing the same.  
Link to study for those interested (definitely not ELI5): https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06921-9 
edit: 3 words for clarity Edit 2: I mixed up my satiety hormones — endocrinologists here pointed out that I meant ghrelin, not leptin, so I fixed that. Hopefully I haven’t mutilated the formatting making edits on mobile browser.

There’s many reasons but the main 3 are security features, device compatibility, and new things being added.
The big one (and reason to regularly update) is security. Imagine securing software like trying to make a door that only you can walk through. After you use it enough times, other people trying to also walk through that door (steal your data, personal info, or financial info) might pick up on patterns and think of ways of keeping the door propped open, messing with the locks, etc. Security updates close these loopholes and keep the door only opening for you.
Another one is new devices. An app might’ve been written for the iPhone X but a few years later we’re now on the iPhone 15 with a completely different operating system and features that didn’t exist when the app was written. It needs to know how to recognize and interact with that new OS (and any future updates to the OS) or it could introduce bugs and crash the app.
Finally, and most straight forward, is them adding new stuff to the software. As people use something they provide feedback and the company uses updates to add that feedback into the software.

question: ¿Por qué es el oro tan valioso? ¿Y por qué es más valioso que otros metales, como la plata?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta! El oro es considerado un metal precioso y valioso debido a su rareza, durabilidad y propiedades únicas. A continuación, te explico algunas razones por las que el oro es tan valioso y por qué es más valioso que otros metales, como la plata:

1. Rareza: El oro es un metal relativamente raro en la naturaleza, lo que lo hace más valioso. Se estima que solo hay unos 193.000 toneladas de oro en todo el mundo, lo que lo hace más escaso que otros metales como la plata o el cobre.
2. Durabilidad: El oro es muy resistente y no se oxida fácilmente, lo que lo hace ideal para la fabricación de joyería, monedas y otros objetos que requieren una alta resistencia y durabilidad.
3. Conductividad eléctrica: El oro es un excelente conductor de electricidad, lo que lo hace ideal para la fabricación de circuitos electrónicos y otros dispositivos electrónicos.
4. No reacciona con otros elementos: El oro no reacciona con otros elementos químicos, lo que lo hace ideal para la fabricación de objetos que requieren una alta pureza y resistencia a la corrosión.
5. Atractivo estético: El oro tiene un atractivo estético natural, lo que lo hace popular para la fabricación de joyería y otros objetos decorativos.

En comparación con la plata, el oro es más valioso debido a su rareza y durabilidad. La plata es un metal más común y se puede encontrar en mayor cantidad en la naturaleza. Además, la plata es más propensa a oxidarse y reaccionar con otros elementos químicos, lo que la hace menos ideal para la fabricación de objetos que requieren una alta resistencia y durabilidad.

En resumen, el oro es valioso debido a su rareza, durabilidad, conductividad eléctrica, no reacción con otros elementos y atractivo estético. Estas propiedades lo hacen ideal para la fabricación de objetos que requieren una alta resistencia y durabilidad, lo que lo hace más valioso que otros metales, como la plata.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Spanish. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Spanish:
5,000 years ago humans didn't know much about metal, metalworking, geology, or mining. But they did have a sense for fashion.
Most metals exist naturally as rock. The metal atoms are connected to other kinds of elements like silicon and they don't look very interesting (to a non-geologist). In the world before the Bronze Age, the only metals most humans would recognize were silver and gold.
Gold can be found as "nuggets" or "dust". The processes that bring it to the surface tends to deposit it in veins so that if you find some, you're likely to find more. Typically it is exposed by weather and flushed downhill into rivers, so finding gold means finding a river with some gold or silver in it, and then looking for more - you don't have to mine it.
You can work gold without heat. It is "malleable" at room temperature, which means you can whack on it with hammers to change the shape of a lump of gold and bend it with tongs - and even though it is malleable it won't lose its new shape once you finish working it and that means you can make useful things.
Gold will not hold an edge so it is useless as a blade. It is much denser than most other materials so it would make a good club, but you don't get much more head-bashing advantage with a gold cub than you would with stone or even wood. So other than as jewelry and as decoration, gold has little practical "use" to an ancient human.
But it is pretty. Aesthetically gold looks "good" next to human skin tones. Why this is so is pretty much a mystery. But it's obvious that people found gold attractive very very early in human development.
Who gets jewelry? Rich people. In the ancient world "rich" was defined as "don't have to farm". There were only three kinds of people like that: royalty, high priests, and successful generals.
Since gold was in limited supply - but there was enough of it that people would recognize it and value it, and it wasn't good for any practical use, and as a metal it would "stay all in one place" and didn't have to be kept in jars or otherwise contained, it became a way for rich people to display their wealth.
Gold is pretty easy to purify and to determine purity (it's a simple weight/volume calculation). That means that it could be exchanged between people for like value - a fixed amount of gold, of a certain purity, was "worth" some number of sheep or sheaves of wheat, or slaves, or land, or whatever. It became a unit of currency due to intrinsic properties convenient for anyone to access - all I need is a scale, a cup, some water, and a little math and I can figure out how much your gold is worth to me.
5,000 years of humans accepting gold as valuable has imbued it with a certain advantage vs. other similar metals. Nobody wants to exchange plutonium coins, even though plutonium is worth, ounce for ounce, vastly more than gold. Gold turns out to have practical uses for modern humans that ancient humans didn't know about - it's an extraordinarily good conductor of electricity. And it still looks good next to human skin.

question: ¿Cómo puede la falta de sueño matar a alguien?
model_answer:
La falta de sueño, también conocida como insomnio crónico, puede tener efectos graves en la salud y, en algunos casos, puede ser mortal. A continuación, te presento algunos de los posibles riesgos y consecuencias graves que puede tener la falta de sueño:

1. **Deterioro cognitivo**: La falta de sueño puede afectar la función cerebral, lo que puede llevar a problemas de concentración, memoria y capacidad de aprendizaje.
2. **Problemas de salud cardiovascular**: La falta de sueño puede aumentar el riesgo de enfermedades cardíacas, como la hipertensión, la enfermedad coronaria y la muerte súbita.
3. **Deterioro inmunológico**: La falta de sueño puede debilitar el sistema inmunológico, lo que puede hacer que el cuerpo sea más propenso a enfermedades infecciosas.
4. **Problemas de salud mental**: La falta de sueño puede aumentar el riesgo de depresión, ansiedad, trastornos de estrés postraumático y otros trastornos mentales.
5. **Problemas de salud digestiva**: La falta de sueño puede afectar la función digestiva, lo que puede llevar a problemas como la diarrea, la constipación y el dolor abdominal crónico.
6. **Problemas de salud reproductiva**: La falta de sueño puede afectar la función reproductiva en hombres y mujeres, lo que puede llevar a problemas de fertilidad y embarazo.
7. **Muerte prematura**: La falta de sueño crónica puede aumentar el riesgo de muerte prematura, ya que puede debilitar el sistema inmunológico y aumentar el riesgo de enfermedades crónicas.

Es importante destacar que la falta de sueño no es solo un problema de comodidad, sino que puede tener consecuencias graves para la salud. Es importante buscar ayuda médica si se experimenta problemas para dormir o si se siente que el sueño es un problema crónico.

La falta de sueño puede afectar a varios sistemas del cuerpo, incluyendo el sistema nervioso, el cardiovascular, el inmunológico y el endocrino. Algunos de los efectos negativos del insomnio crónico incluyen:

question: ¿Por qué los humanos no pueden quedar embarazados de animales?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta!

La razón por la que los humanos no pueden quedar embarazados de animales es debido a la biología y la evolución de los seres vivos. Hay varios factores que lo impiden:

1. Diferencia en el número de cromosomas: Los seres humanos tienen 46 cromosomas, mientras que la mayoría de los animales tienen un número diferente de cromosomas. Esto hace que sea imposible que los espermatozoides humanos se fusionen con los óvulos de los animales.
2. Diferencia en la estructura del espermatozoide: Los espermatozoides humanos tienen una cabeza, una cola y una cola flagelada, mientras que los espermatozoides de los animales tienen una estructura diferente. Esto hace que sea difícil que los espermatozoides humanos se unan con los óvulos de los animales.
3. Diferencia en la química y la bioquímica: Los seres humanos y los animales tienen diferentes químicos y bioquímicos en su cuerpo, lo que hace que sea difícil que los espermatozoides humanos se unan con los óvulos de los animales.
4. Evolución: La evolución ha seleccionado a los seres humanos para reproducirse con otros seres humanos, no con animales. Esto ha llevado a la evolución de características que permiten la reproducción entre seres humanos, pero no con animales.

En resumen, la combinación de la diferencia en el número de cromosomas, la estructura del espermatozoide, la química y la bioquímica, y la evolución han hecho que sea imposible que los humanos queden embarazados de animales.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Spanish. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Spanish:
When a human baby is to be made, the egg (half of the blueprint and all of the necessary machinery) absorbs a sperm. The sperm brings the rest of the blueprint.
If the sperm isn't set up to enter the egg, or if the blueprints don't fit together at all, or if the thing created by the blueprints cannot survive, then nothing comes of it.

Translate the following question from English into Spanish. Make it sound as natural as possible:
Why can't humans get pregnant from animals?
persona: You are a biologist with a specialization in reproductive biology and genetics, with a strong background in human and animal physiology. You have a deep understanding of the biological and genetic mechanisms that govern reproduction in both humans and animals. You are familiar with the concept of species-specific reproductive isolation and the genetic barriers that prevent interspecies breeding. You have a strong foundation in evolutionary biology and the principles of natural selection, which inform your understanding of the adaptations that have developed in different species to ensure their reproductive success. You are well-versed in the scientific literature on human and animal reproduction and are able to draw upon this knowledge to provide accurate and informative responses.
persona_model_answer:
La capacidad de los humanos para quedar embarazados de animales es limitada por la barrera de especie, que se refiere a la incapacidad de dos especies diferentes para producir descendencia viables. En el caso de los humanos y los animales, esta barrera se debe a la incompatibilidad entre el ADN de los gametos humanos y el ADN de los gametos animales.

En los seres humanos, el ADN está compuesto por 23 pares de cromosomas, lo que da un total de 46 cromosomas en cada célula somática. Los gametos humanos, es decir, los espermatozoides y los óvulos, tienen 23 cromosomas cada uno, lo que se conoce como haploidía. En contraste, los animales tienen un número diferente de cromosomas en sus células somáticas y gametos, lo que hace que la fertilización entre especies sea imposible.

Además, incluso si se lograra fertilizar un óvulo humano con un espermatozoide animal, la embriogénesis sería improbable debido a la incompatibilidad entre el ADN de los gametos. El ADN de los gametos humanos y animales es tan diferente que no podrían combinarse de manera efectiva para formar un embrión viable.

En resumen, la barrera de especie entre los humanos y los animales es una combinación de la incompatibilidad entre el número de cromosomas y la diferencia en el ADN de los gametos, lo que hace que la fertilización y la formación de un embrión viable sean imposibles.
ground_truth: When a human baby is to be made, the egg (half of the blueprint and all of the necessary machinery) absorbs a sperm. The sperm brings the rest of the blueprint. If the sperm isn't set up to enter the egg, or if the blueprints don't fit together at all, or if the thing created by the blueprints cannot survive, then nothing comes of it.

question: ¿Cómo sabe mi teléfono cuándo estoy durmiendo?
model_answer:
Excelente pregunta!

Tu teléfono puede detectar cuando estás durmiendo de varias maneras. Aquí hay algunas posibles formas:

1. **Movimiento y actividad**: Tu teléfono puede utilizar el acelerómetro y el giroscopio para detectar el movimiento y la actividad que realizas. Si no hay movimiento ni actividad durante un período prolongado, puede suponer que estás durmiendo.
2. **Luz y sonido**: Tu teléfono puede medir la luz y el sonido que entra en el entorno. Si la luz es baja y no hay sonido significativo, puede indicar que estás en un entorno tranquilo y probablemente estés durmiendo.
3. **Pulsaciones y ritmo cardíaco**: Algunos teléfonos pueden utilizar el sensor de pulsaciones para medir tu ritmo cardíaco. Si el ritmo cardíaco es lento y constante, puede indicar que estás durmiendo.
4. **Análisis de patrones de actividad**: Algunos teléfonos pueden analizar tus patrones de actividad diaria, incluyendo el momento en que sueles dormir y despertar. Si el teléfono detecta que no hay actividad durante un período prolongado, puede suponer que estás durmiendo.
5. **Acceso a la ubicación**: Algunos teléfonos pueden utilizar la información de la ubicación para determinar si estás en un entorno que es común para dormir, como tu hogar o un hotel.

Es importante destacar que estos métodos no son infalibles y pueden tener errores. Si deseas que tu teléfono no te despierte durante el sueño, es recomendable configurar las opciones de notificaciones y silencio en tu teléfono para que no te molesten durante el sueño.

4. **Agricultura y silvicultura**: La agricultura y la silvicultura pueden influir en el clima a través de la plantación de árboles y la gestión de ecosistemas. Los árboles y los bosques pueden absorber dióxido de carbono y producir oxígeno, lo que puede ayudar a mitigar el cambio climático.

Bicycle (and motorcycle) dynamics are very complex. Physicists and mathematicians have been having trouble modeling exactly what makes two wheeled vehicles stable. Here's one stab at it.
Some things are known to increase stability. The gyroscopic effect of the wheels plays a minor role. As /u/bjujey pointed out below, experiments have shown that removing the gyroscopic effect still makes for a stable bike.
Trail also plays a role. Trail is the measurement of where the steering axis in relation to the contact of the wheel on the ground. Here's a picture for illustration. This is also called the caster effect. Basically the further forward the steering axis is from wheel contact with the ground, the more stable the bike. Track bikes and cyclocross bikes have really short trail to make them more agile. Big stable cruisers have long trails.
Like gyroscopic effect, experiments have removed trail as a variable and these models are also stable. Here is an interview with a scientist who removed both gyroscopic and caster/trail effects in a model bicycle, and it remained stable.
tl;dr: No one really knows what makes a moving bike stable.

Some things are known to increase stability. The gyroscopic effect of the wheels plays a minor role. As /u/bjujey pointed out below, experiments have shown that removing the gyroscopic effect still makes for a stable bike.
Trail also plays a role. Trail is the measurement of where the steering axis in relation to the contact of the wheel on the ground. Here's a picture for illustration. Like gyroscopic effect, experiments have removed trail as a variable and these models are also stable. Here is an interview with a scientist who removed both gyroscopic and caster/trail effects in a model bicycle, and it remained stable.

old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Tswana. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Tswana:
The short version is: the developing fetus makes hormones that make mom feel sick (if mom's body isn't used to the hormone). 
Hormones are chemical messengers that float around your body and are like snail mail that an organ sends to another organ. For example, when you eat and your stomach gets full, it releases a hormone called ghrelin. When ghrelin reaches your brain, your brain gets the "stop eating" message (that's why it takes 15 or so minutes to feel full after a meal—snail mail, relatively speaking). 
It was published a few months ago that a hormone called GDF15 is likely behind morning sickness. One place where GDF15 messages go is to a brain region called the solitary tract, and that brain region controls the gag reflex and vomiting. People produce different levels of GDF15, depending on genetics, diet, and some other factors. Some people have naturally high GDF15 levels and some have low levels. Fetuses produce a lot of GDF15 it turns out, so it was recently found that pregnant mothers who had low levels of GDF15 before becoming pregnant were more likely to experience morning sickness. 
 The growing fetus is releasing chemicals that basically push the "vomit button" in mom's brain, but if mom's already used to having that button pushed, they aren't going to be as affected by the fetus. It's like how a seasoned drinker could hammer back a row of shots without, well, vomiting, whereas someone who's never had a drink in their life is going to have a bad time doing the same.  
Link to study for those interested (definitely not ELI5): https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06921-9 
edit: 3 words for clarity Edit 2: I mixed up my satiety hormones — endocrinologists here pointed out that I meant ghrelin, not leptin, so I fixed that. Hopefully I haven’t mutilated the formatting making edits on mobile browser.

question: Ke ka ntlha yang fa go goga motsoko go kotsi thata mo pelong?
model_answer: Ke ka ntlha yang fa go goga motsoko go kotsi thata mo pelong, ke go tshwenyega ka kgosi. Ke go tshwenyega ka kgosi, ke go tshwenyega ka kgosi, ke go tshwenyega ka kgosi.
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Tswana. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Tswana:
A heart attack is what happens when something (a blood clot, a bit of fat/cholesterol/plaque, etc) blocks one the arteries that supply blood and nutrients to the heart. Smoking impacts this in two ways. First, it causes your blood to thicken and clot more easily, which means clots are more likely to form inside your blood vessels where they're not supposed to. Second, it irritates the lining of your blood vessels, causing them to swell and become less flexible, which makes them narrower and easier to clog. This is also why smoking increases the risk of stroke, which is when the same thing happens to an artery leading to the brain.
It's also worth mentioning that both of those effects are temporary. According to the CDC, the increased risk largely goes away within a year of quitting smoking. However, heart damage from actually having a heart attack is permanent.

question: Lu tax juróomi dëkk yi am ay dund gu tollu ci bépp?
model_answer: Wuñu! Lu tax juróomi dëkk yi am ay dund gu tollu ci bépp, ngi xarit ay wuñu! (Ahah, you want to know how to get to the other side of the bridge, right? Well, I'll help you with that!)
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Wolof. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Wolof:
Life span is a pretty complicated topic, but we can understand it by using what is known as life history theory.  This is basically the idea that the timing of life events such as how long an animal grows, when and how many times it reproduces, and when it dies are developed through the process of natural selection.  As such, total lifespan for a given species has evolved in a manner similar to any other adaptation, and is related to what will allow that animal to survive, and more importantly, to reproduce in a given environment.
So what are some factors that influence life history and life span?
Life history and average age at death are often linked to body size, and with some exceptions (like bats) larger body size is associated with a longer life span.  For example, mice live a year or maybe two and have what we call a “fast” life history, while a large whale or elephant will live for decades with a “slow” life history.  But why do some animals have a fast life and some a slow life?
Part of this can be explained by looking at extrinsic mortality and how animals have to partition their energetic resources.  An animal can put its energy into either growth, bodily maintenance or reproduction. However energy input is ultimately limited by the environment, so an animal cannot invest into all three infinitely and must therefore partition how much effort it will place into each of these categories. Basically, do you grow a lot, get big, and reproduce only a few offspring? Or do you grow quickly, stay small and reproduce a lot of kids?
One thing that helps decide this is that all animals face extrinsic mortality - basically the likelihood you’ll be taken out by another animal (e.g. predation) or by the environment (e.g., changing seasons, flooding, etc.). If you are faced with high extrinsic mortality, this favors getting in the game reproductively early in life.  In these species you in turn see less investment in growth and bodily maintenance.  They therefore tend to be small, live a short period of time and produce a lot of kids they don’t put a ton of investment into.  Think mice, mayflies and the like.  In contrast, animals with lower extrinsic mortality tend to take time to grow larger (which also further reduces extrinsic mortality), and take a longer time reproducing a smaller number of individuals whom they put a lot of investment into getting to survive their growth into adulthood (think primates, whales and elephants).  
As long-lived, smart primates we often think of our “slow” life history as “better” than a mouse’s short life.  It’s important to recognize that these are simply different, but equally effective, strategies for getting your genes into the next generation.  While a slow life history allows for the development of things like our big brain and tapping on a phone, our mouse friends ultimately have pretty effective strategy in terms of natural selection as well. I’ve really only scratched the surface here, and there are a ton of other factors to look at when it comes to lifespan (e.g., BMR, phylogenetic effects, etc.), but if you are interested there is a lot out there on life history theory.

It's like how a seasoned drinker could hammer back a row of shots without, well, vomiting, whereas someone who's never had a drink in their life is going to have a bad time doing the same.  
Link to study for those interested (definitely not ELI5): https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06921-9

ground_truth: The short version is: the developing fetus makes hormones that make mom feel sick (if mom's body isn't used to the hormone). Hormones are chemical messengers that float around your body and are like snail mail that an organ sends to another organ. For example, when you eat and your stomach gets full, it releases a hormone called ghrelin. When ghrelin reaches your brain, your brain gets the "stop eating" message (that's why it takes 15 or so minutes to feel full after a meal—snail mail, relatively speaking). It was published a few months ago that a hormone called GDF15 is likely behind morning sickness. One place where GDF15 messages go is to a brain region called the solitary tract, and that brain region controls the gag reflex and vomiting. People produce different levels of GDF15, depending on genetics, diet, and some other factors. Some people have naturally high GDF15 levels and some have low levels. Fetuses produce a lot of GDF15 it turns out, so it was recently found that pregnant mothers who had low levels of GDF15 before becoming pregnant were more likely to experience morning sickness. The growing fetus is releasing chemicals that basically push the "vomit button" in mom's brain, but if mom's already used to having that button pushed, they aren't going to be as affected by the fetus. It's like how a seasoned drinker could hammer back a row of shots without, well, vomiting, whereas someone who's never had a drink in their life is going to have a bad time doing the same. Link to study for those interested (definitely not ELI5): https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06921-9 edit: 3 words for clarity Edit 2: I mixed up my satiety hormones — endocrinologists here pointed out that I meant ghrelin, not leptin, so I fixed that. question: Samay waxtu, damaa fent ne dëkk bi ci Taiwan moo jur ñiari microchips yi gën a màgg ci àdduna bi te kenn mënul a defaraat leen. Nan la ko moomu ame?
model_answer:
Wuñu wuñu! Samay waxtu, damaa fent ne dëkk bi ci Taiwan moo jur ñiari microchips yi gën a màgg ci àdduna bi te kenn mënul a defaraat leen. Nan la ko moomu ame?

Moomu ame, Taiwan waxtu, damaa fent ne dëkk bi ci àdduna bi te kenn mënul a defaraat leen. Dëkk bi ci Taiwan, nan la ko moomu ame, nan la ko moomu ame. Wuñu wuñu!
old_ground_truth:
Your task is to translate a question from English into Wolof. You will be given the English answer as the context.

Here is the English answer. Use it as the context to make the translation sound natural in the Wolof:
That's not entirely true
TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited) is one of the premiere chip manufacturing companies in the world but they are hardly the only one.
They are of note because they make everything from common chips used in everything from cars to cellphones to AMDs processors. Apple, Nvidia, AMD, and Qualcomm for example all use TSMC to manufacture their chips.
But Samsung (Korea) and Intel (US) also have chip foundries of that caliber.
TSMCs secret is just that they have large numbers of highly experienced people working for them and have developed very good processes. Samsung and Intel are similar in that regard, but TSMC is special in that the Taiwanese government has in a sense made semiconductor manufacturing the countries primary industry.
Other companies like Texas instruments can also make microchips and have facilities all over the US but can't make chips as complex as Computer microprocessors. Importantly though there's nothing stopping them from investing capital to build such a facility, they just don't want to. (Developing an in house microprocessor to compete with AMD and Intel at this point would require an outrageous investment)
Israel is also another big up and comer in chip manufacturing.
Why TSMC is of note is the Pandemic showed just how vulnerable the US and the West are to losing access to TSMC production. If China for example were to invade Taiwan it could be a really big problem for the economy and availability of these chips.
This is why TSMC is building a Chip Foundry in Texas Arizona right now so chip production can happen domestically in the US.
